item.title: Unzipped, Unplugged and Still Unfiltered, Darling
item.description: As he celebrates his 10th year at Café Carlyle — and his quippy turn in “Marty Supreme” — we catch up with Isaac Mizrahi.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Iredale
item.media:credit: Justin J Wee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Isaac Supreme: Mr. Mizrahi at home in January.

item.title: ’The Devil Wears Prada 2’ Trailer Promises a Nostalgia Trip
item.description: But will it be delightful or depressing to watch Andy and Miranda navigate the current fashion media landscape?
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk

item.title: Westminster Dog Show 2026: Behind-the-Scenes Photos
item.description: Brushing, panting, licking and leaping: Here’s what we saw backstage, where show dogs could let their fur down before taking to the ring.
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk, Lanna Apisukh and Amir Hamja
item.category: Javits, Jacob K, Convention Center (Manhattan, NY)
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: A well-groomed bichon frisé will stand out almost anywhere, but against the purple carpeting in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, one can truly pop.

item.title: A Closer Look at Mamdani’s Custom Carhartt Jacket
item.description: As he dealt with a major snowstorm, Mayor Zohran Mamdani appeared in a personalized Carhartt jacket designed with help from the first lady.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:description: Speaking to New Yorkers about a recent snowstorm, Mayor Zohran Mamdani of New York City wore a Carhartt jacket with embroidery that included a throwback municipal logo, which is also featured on merchandise from Only NY, a local skate brand.

item.title: Will the Spirit of 1976 Come to 2026?
item.description: Bicentennial celebrations across America were spirited and joyous. As the semiquincentennial approaches, there’s a different mood.
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz
item.media:description: Buster Smith, in Revolutionary garb, took part in an anti-big-business protest held by the People’s Bicentennial Commission at the Washington Monument on July 4, 1976.

item.title: The Subtle Marketing Move Behind Justin Bieber’s Grammys Boxers
item.description: The singer, who was nominated for four Grammys, performed at the award show in nothing but sparkly lavender shorts and socks.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher
item.media:description: Look more closely, and the satiny shorts contained the logo for the singer’s clothing brand in tiny crystals.

item.title: 2026 Grammys Red Carpet Photos: Chappell Roan, Tyla, Lady Gaga and More
item.description: See what nominees and guests for the 68th Grammy Awards, including Addison Rae, Bad Bunny and Doechii, wore to arrive to the ceremony.
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk
item.media:description: Addison Rae, a nominee for best new artist, arrived in Alaïa on the red carpet in Los Angeles on Sunday evening.

item.title: Kristin Sudeikis Is A Dance Fitness Star with Celebrity in Her Blood
item.description: Through her dance company and studio, Forward Space, where models and actresses come to sweat, Kristin Sudeikis has earned fame of her own.
item.dc:creator: Laura Neilson and Shuran Huang
item.media:description: The actor Jason Sudeikis, Ms. Sudeikis’s older brother, described his sister as being laser-focused on her profession. “She’s here to dance,” he said.

item.title: Wager, a smooth fox terrier, wins the terrier group.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:credit: Lanna Apisukh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amy Rutherford leading Wager, who turned 2 just last week, on one of the most successful walks of his young life.

item.title: Catherine O’Hara, Star of ‘Best in Show,’ Honored in Westminster Tribute
item.description: Fans remembered the actress, who died last week at 71, for her role as the doting owner of a Norwich terrier destined for glory in the movie, a sendup of dog show culture.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:credit: Doane Gregory/Online USA, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Catherine O’Hara as Cookie Fleck, a Florida dog lover with a past, in Christopher Guest’s “Best in Show.” Her hapless husband, Gerry (Eugene Levy), rose to the occasion in the film’s fictional dog show.

item.title: Penny, a Doberman pinscher, wins the working group.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:credit: Lanna Apisukh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andy Linton and Penny emerged victorious from a competitive working group.

item.title: Cota, a Chesapeake Bay retriever, wins the sporting group.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:credit: Lanna Apisukh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cota (above, with his handler, Devon Kipp Levy) bested his fellow athletes in the sporting group to be named best in group.

item.title: The top judge is partial to Pekingese, but only at home.
item.description: David Fitzpatrick has led two Pekingese to Westminster glory, but when it comes time to select best in show, he knows “how to appreciate all dogs.”
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wasabi (above in 2021, being held like a vintage bread box bought for a song at an estate sale) is the second Pekingese to capture best in show at Westminster for David Fitzpatrick.

item.title: A lifelong lover of Dobermans reclaims best in show after 37 years.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall and Callie Holtermann

item.title: Four dogs have already advanced to best in show judging.
item.description: The winners of Monday’s hound, toy, non-sporting and herding group judging will return on Tuesday night.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:credit: Lanna Apisukh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Willy Santiago led Zaida the Afghan hound — along with her several Rapunzels’ worth of blond tresses — around the ring. She was named best in the hound group on Monday.

item.title: Last year, Monty trounced the competition.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:description: The A.K.C. breed standard for the giant schnauzer calls for ears “set high on the skull and carried perpendicularly.” Above, the ears of a champion.

item.title: Tom Britt, Designer of Larger-Than-Life Interiors, Dies at 89
item.description: A master of the grand gesture, he was as theatrical as his rooms, which were inspired by French chateaus and Italian palazzos. As he put it, “Why be ordinary?”
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

item.title: Everyone Is Missing the Point About the ‘Melania’ Movie
item.description: It’s not really a movie at all. It’s a marketing deck.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:description: Melania Trump at the screening of “Melania” at the Kennedy Center last week.

item.title: Street Style Look of the Week: Vintage Fur Coats
item.description: A couple strolling through London were sporting fuzzy secondhand coats.
item.dc:creator: Simbarashe Cha

item.title: How to Watch the 2026 Westminster Dog Show
item.description: Everything you (and your dog) need to know about the competition, now in its 150th outing.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:description: Monty, a giant schnauzer who enjoys chewing on soccer balls, won best in show at last year’s Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

item.title: John Forté, Who Forged a Hip-Hop Redemption Tale, Dies at 50
item.description: He seemed destined for a glittering career, working with the Fugees and solo, and then landed in prison. After his sentence was commuted, he clawed his way back.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:description: John Forté in 2010. His rise in the music industry was swift, but his fall came just as quickly, when he was convicted of acting as a middleman in a scheme to transport $1.4 million worth of liquid cocaine.

item.title: Are Models Getting Even Skinnier?
item.description: The era of size inclusivity is seemingly over. Our critic traces the shift and hopes designers might learn from it.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:description: The backlash to “wokeness” has swept up size inclusivity on the runway.

item.title: Unforgettable Grammys 2026 Looks: Chappell Roan, Sabrina Carpenter, Bad Bunny
item.description: Feathered gowns, sequined suits, freed nipples and more.
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk
item.media:description: Lady Gaga was one of many artists who embraced feathers at the Grammy Awards.

item.title: Chappell Roan’s Nipple Piercing Dress Brought Naked Dressing to the Grammys
item.description: Chappell Roan’s dress draped a barely there translucent skirt from nipple piercings, and that wasn’t the only way celebrities bared their skin.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:description: Chappell Roan arrived in a burgundy, opaque chiffon cape, a custom design by Mugler. Below her cape, an opaque floor-length skirt hung in place from nipple piercings.

item.title: Westminster 2026: Yes, Some Show Dogs Still Have Day Jobs
item.description: Nick, a Tibetan spaniel, is a therapy dog at a senior living center in Washington. He is one of several champion show dogs that have busy lives outside of the competition.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall and Ruth Fremson
item.media:description: Most residents at the center are not able to care for a dog of their own, so Nick’s visits are a huge morale boost.

item.title: Usha Vance’s Pregnancy Becomes a Talking Point
item.description: The announcement that the second family is expecting a fourth child has turned Ms. Vance into a symbol of success for proponents of conservative family values.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:description: Usha Vance, the eldest of two daughters of Indian immigrants, initially thought that she was more or less done growing her family after she had her third child.

item.title: Modern Weddings, With Multiple Dresses and Looks, Turn Into Fashion Extravaganzas
item.description: Some couples are turning their weddings into fashion extravaganzas, with multiple outfit changes.
item.dc:creator: Mina Llona

item.title: Paris Couture Week Is Where Moguls and Movie Stars Shop For Clothes
item.description: The global elite mingled at couture week in Paris, where the world’s most exquisite attire was displayed on runways and streets.
item.dc:creator: Simbarashe Cha
item.media:description: Valentino spring 2026 couture.

item.title: ‘Heated Rivalry’ Fans Want the Fleece. They’ll Be Able to Get It.
item.description: American and Canadian “Heated Rivalry” fans are hot for the jacket worn by the character Shane Hollander.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez

item.title: In Minneapolis, Red ‘Melt the Ice’ Hats Are Being Knitted by Activists
item.description: The red tasseled hats are at the heart of a movement to galvanize opposition to Immigration and Custom Enforcement in Minnesota and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Jesse McKinley and Liam James Doyle
item.media:description: Known as “Melt the ICE” caps, the pattern for the knitted hat — selling at $5 — has been ordered more than 85,000 times since being offered online in mid-January, according to the Minneapolis-area shop behind its creation.

item.title: Is the ‘Influencer Right’ at Odds With Trump Over Minnesota?
item.description: A vocal group of Trump supporters broke with the president when he appeared to backpedal on his immigration crackdown in Minneapolis. Is it a rift, or just a passing mood?
item.dc:creator: Nathan Taylor Pemberton
item.media:credit: From left, Jason Andrew for The New York Times; Jim Watson/AFP — Getty Images; Jason Davis/Getty Images; John Locher/Associated Press; Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Stephen K. Bannon, Nick Sortor, Matt Walsh, Andrew Kolvet and Nicholas Fuentes, who criticized President Trump after he appeared to temper his immigration crackdown in Minneapolis.

item.title: How Childhood Play Dates Turned Into an Eventual Wedding Date
item.description: Bevan Cohen and Ryan Boesky grew up together. He had a crush on her in kindergarten; it wasn’t reciprocated until high school.
item.dc:creator: Sophia June

item.title: He Planned Two More Dates Before the First Week Ended
item.description: Samantha Lesser and Michael Wald met through family connections and quickly found themselves planning what came next.
item.dc:creator: Donna Kim

item.title: Love Took Flight With Birds of a Feather
item.description: Emily Diamond and David Meadows are serious birders who found each other on Hinge.
item.dc:creator: Rosalie R. Radomsky

item.title: ‘Hey, How’s It Going? I’m Filing for Divorce Now.’
item.description: Marriage is hard. It can be even harder when you don’t believe you deserve to be loved in the first place.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Huiyang Wang

item.title: How Benjamin Franklin Helped Bring Them Together
item.description: Breana Teubner and Peter McGuiness hit it off on their first date. She asked him to name a favorite autobiography. His answer impressed.
item.dc:creator: Linda Marx

item.title: Melania Trump Documentary Premiere: Who Was at the Kennedy Center
item.description: Top White House officials streamed into the Kennedy Center on Thursday for a screening of Amazon’s new documentary about the first lady, Melania Trump.
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: President Trump and the first lady, Melania Trump, arriving at the Kennedy Center on Thursday for the premiere of “Melania,” Amazon’s new documentary about Mrs. Trump.

item.title: How to Make Friends as an Adult: 11 Ways to Build Lasting Connections
item.description: A practical guide for expanding your circle, with advice from sociable people.
item.dc:creator: Laura Regensdorf

item.title: Ben Sinclair Addresses His Complicated Relationship to Weed on Substack
item.description: The “High Maintenance” co-creator and star Ben Sinclair delves into his complicated relationship with marijuana in a new Substack called “Low Maintenance.”
item.dc:creator: Kasia Pilat
item.media:description: Ben Sinclair’s essays, published on his new Substack, are vulnerable and reflective.

item.title: Saks Fifth Avenue Bankruptcy Revives Debate Over the Future of Department Stores
item.description: Saks Fifth Avenue’s bankruptcy filing has revived debates about how these once celebrated shopping emporiums can regain their luster.
item.dc:creator: Ginia Bellafante
item.media:description: The New York Visitors Information Bureau had a counter at Bloomingdale’s in 1964.

item.title: Couture Is the Place to Find Fantastic Creatures
item.description: Schiaparelli and Valentino turn the runways of Paris into a surreal experience.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman

item.title: How You Wear Your Winter Scarf Could Be Revealing Your Age
item.description: Some have given the act of putting on a scarf new meaning, one that can be tinged with anxiety.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:description: Arguments about scarf styling are rooted in the divide between Gen Z-ers and millennials, whose style choices are often used as a line demarcating what looks youthful and what looks old.

item.title: My Parents Did Nothing to Stop My Bullying
item.description: Our Ask the Therapist columnist, Lori Gottlieb, advises a reader who is seeking closure after a tumultuous childhood.
item.dc:creator: Lori Gottlieb

item.title: ‘Wuthering Heights’ Finds New Fans Ahead of Emerald Fennell’s Film Adaptation
item.description: To prepare for Emerald Fennell’s film adaptation, a new generation of readers is seeking out Emily Brontë’s Gothic novel — and the “unhinged gossip” it contains.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann and Lila Barth
item.media:credit: Lila Barth for The New York Times

item.title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘The Cooler, Funnier Version of Myself’
item.description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.

item.title: Rama Duwaji Joins New Yorkers at an Art Party
item.description: The city’s first lady showed up for a night out with artists, writers and celebrities at the Whitney Museum’s winter fund-raiser.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vadukul and Nina Westervelt
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times

item.title: Sydney Sweeney Launches Lingerie Brand Syrn With Hollywood Sign Stunt
item.description: The actress proved, once again, she has a knack for thriving in the attention economy.
item.dc:creator: Yola Mzizi
item.media:description: Sydney Sweeney, who is no stranger to controversy, pulled off a marketing stunt that could land her in hot water.

item.title: A Big Day for Thigh-High Boots on Men
item.description: Paris men’s fashion week comes to a close with Saint Laurent.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher
item.media:description: Something Alexander Skarsgard might have worn on his press tour for “Pillion.”

item.title: Why Do Houseguests Expect Us to Pay for Any Food During Their Visits?
item.description: A married couple is unsure how to get guests at their vacation home to pony up for groceries — ideally without being asked.
item.dc:creator: Philip Galanes

item.title: Being the Fun Dad Almost Destroyed My Marriage
item.description: For years, Jordan Carlos left most of the chores and child care to his wife. By the time he realized he didn’t want to be that guy anymore, it was almost too late.
item.dc:creator: Anna Martin, Reva Goldberg, Jen Poyant, Lynn Levy, Daniel Ramirez, Elisheba Ittoop, Dan Powell and Aman Sahota

item.title: Hey, ChatGPT: Where Should I Go to College?
item.description: High schoolers are turning to chatbots for help navigating the college admissions process. Does a virtual college coach know what’s best for students?
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.category: National Assn for College Admission Counseling
item.media:credit: Andrew Spear for The New York Times

item.title: In Couture, Chanel Celebrates Older Women
item.description: In his first couture show, the designer Matthieu Blazy changes the rules.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:description: Stephanie Cavalli opens the Chanel show.
